posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked:
Due to fire codes, we’re losing a shed behind our school (near our room) where we store wood and metal stock, so we have to bring the metal back into the shop. The team has existed for over a decade & has accumulated a lot of “usable scrap” and “misc inventory” (widely varying sizes of bar, round tube, and a whole lot more).

Our metal shop is not large, and we’re going to have to let a lot of stuff go. There’s a metal shop at the local makerspace that will take some of it off our hands, I’m sure.

So… We’re at this inflection point, and I’m curious what teams do about less-used stock and scrap. I think we may shift to keeping in inventory only what we know will be used on robots and getting rid of everything else, and then IF something different is needed in a given season, order it. But that will mean getting rid of a bunch of cool stuff we could eventually use… sometime ;). I frequently go find a piece of scrap to make a piece (bracket or whatever) to solve a little problem, and we’ll be losing some of that. But the space savings probably makes it worth it. Anyway, if you have wisdom to share on this topic, please do. Thanks.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Any chance the shed could be “put on wheels” and parked in a lot… Idk maybe find an old enclosed trailer xD

On a serious note I would get rid if any sheet that is less than 1sq ft of area (by eye), anything that is really scratched up, dented, substantially bent…

posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked: Not really. The school campus is not that large, and we already are challenged with our existing trailer we take to competitions… having to store it in an out-of-the-way spot that is tricky to get in and out of.

posts.name: Nyx
posts.cooked: Sell it to a scrap place if it’s not going to be useful for the next 2 years of competition.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.custom_user_title: Everything and nothing, all at the same time

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
We keep even quite small pieces of aluminum plate and block, and have a couple drawers in some Lista/Vidmar style cabinets for them. It comes in handy a lot.

For tube and bar, we send to recycling any parts that don’t seem worth keeping, which if I’m the one in the shop usually means anything under ~5” except any little churro scrap gets set aside to be over-processed into an integer inch length, tapped, and put into the prototyping totes so we have a nice stock of ready-to-use standoffs. (We also share stock with the engineering classes, so offering them fast-to-use standoffs is a way to keep in the good graces of the engineering dept.)

I think we probably keep a little more than we should (and aren’t alone), but several times every season, it’s rewarded, and we can spare the space, so it persists.

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
We’re notoriously packrats on this, and we’ve got a lot of stock (both tube, angle, lumber, and corrugated plastic) in what was a try-on room in our shop.

When we’ve needed to purge to crunch down space (and that’s happened in the past), we usually just weed out the smallest and most-abused pieces until we’ve hit our target.

We’ve also taken on using up material for other projects.  One of our graduating seniors was an organizational king, and he was the opposite of you and I–the “are we ever gonna use this” factor was big for him.  So when we had one stick of AndyMark Peanut left in the shop, I made a paper sketch of a handle for a new driver station shelf, set him loose in Onshape, and we now have a new driver station .

link_counts.title: Pandamaniacs Present: Printable Driver Station Handle for AndyMark Peanut

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: says you should come to SCRIW in October

posts.name: Ardiano Works
posts.cooked:
When the space is premium, we do this “sorting” exercise frequently.

In our shop, anything less than 6” inch sq get tossed. So, sometimes, We purposely trim the non usable area/remnant from big Polycarb, or Aluminum sheets and tossed those away. We also tossed tubes that have all the lighting holes on them, regardless how long they are. I told the kids to use what we have, this off course has some limitation. Standardize thickness especially thickness and diameter.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
chrisrin:

we could eventually use… sometime

Danger! Danger! Spark joy and pass it along to someone else. If there is a scrap metal business nearby see if they’ll accept stuff for a credit towards a future purchase. You know, when you need some of that scrap back.

Or, build a mobile storage cart. Something that can be stored in the work space when no one is there, and rolled into a hall or outside when the space is in use. Like this that we built:

"One Day Builds" Repository Technical

"One Day Builds" Repository Technical
